Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Computational Intelligence Methods For Dynamic Stochastic Optimization Of Smart Grid Operation With High Penetration Of Renewable Energy

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this research is to develop advanced computational intelligence methods to monitor, optimize and control large or so-called wide areas of a power network that will include solar farms (SFs) and wind farms (WFs), and controllable network transformers (CNTs), in order to ensure optimum usage of all these resources both during slow changing semi-steady state conditions, as well as during transient conditions. The research will be carried out in off-line simulations and then implemented on a real-time simulator.

Intellectual merit
The behavior of renewable energy sources is uncertain and variable, and it is difficult for static optimization methods to optimize uncertain non-stationary distributed energy resources in a smart grid for maximum utilization. A novel ACD controller is proposed for the development of a real- time dynamic stochastic optimization smart grid engine. Advanced intelligent methods such as the biologically inspired artificial neural network and smart devices (CNTs) provide better identification and control capabilities for implementation of optimal power flows.

Broader Impacts
Economically operated reliable and secure power systems that can accommodate high penetration of renewable energy are of national interest. Being able to route power through underutilized lines will have major economic and environmental benefits due to avoiding the need for new lines. This project will have several dissemination channels, including software, websites, new contents added to existing courses, special sessions and tutorials at conferences, and journal publications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project commenced on September 1, 2012. The overarching goal of this proposed collaborative research project was to develop advanced computational intelligence methods to monitor, optimize and control large or so-called wide areas of a power network that will include solar farms (SFs) and wind farms (WFs), traditional generators, controllable network transformers (CNTs) and flexible AC transmission system (FACTS) devices, in order to ensure optimum usage of all these resources both during slow changing semi-steady state conditions, as well as during transient conditions.

A power system is a multi-input multi-output (MIMO), nonlinear, and non-stationary complex dynamic plant, even without wind and solar farms. Due to the stochastic nature of wind and solar energies, when they are integrated into the existing power system, the system becomes even more complex. How to reliably and efficiently operate and control a power system in such an environment was the goal of this project. Neurocontrol offers nonlinear optimal control without the need for any mathematical model of the system, which is particularly useful for the nonlinear, stochastic power systems with uncertainty. The investigators showed that feedforward, recurrent and echo state neural networks are able to identify and optimally control nonlinear non-stationary systems; this was demonstrated on small scale power networks consisting of 12 buses, 3 generators and 2 FACTS devices, represented by a few dozen state variables.

However, practical power networks typically consist of thousands of buses and hundreds of generators and control points with several thousands of sensors scattered throughout large geographic areas. Traditional neural network architectures start to break down as one tries to scale up to thousands of variables. This problem was addressed on 71-bus, 16-generator system (see attached image) with cellular neural networks, adaptive critic designs for dynamic optimization and new brain-inspired neural network architectures that have brain-like scalable performance and are able to make adaptive optimal decisions over time which will be needed for successful smart grid operation.

INTELLECTUAL MERIT

ACD based neurocontrol offers nonlinear optimal control which is particularly useful for the nonlinear stochastic power networks, which would otherwise need different mathematical models and changing parameters for different network topologies. In a changing environment, behavior of renewable energy and plug-in vehicles in a smart grid is uncertain and it is difficult for static optimization methods to optimize uncertain non-stationary distributed energy resources in a smart grid. A novel ACD controller has been developed for  a real- time dynamic stochastic optimization smart grid engine.

 

BROADER IMPACTS

(1) Impact on National Needs: Economically operated reliable and secure power systems that can accommodate high penetration of renewable energy are of national interest. Being able to route power through underutilized lines will have major economical and environmental benefits due to avoiding the need for new lines. Improved intelligent control of the existing power grid will allow reliable integration of alternative clean sources of energy, reduce greenhouse gas emissions, remove line congestion, and avoid cascading failures which lead to blackouts such as that of August 2003. This project offers a unique capability to improve the critical national need of having a reliable, safe and secure electric power grid.
(2) Impact on Graduate and Undergraduate Education: Underrepresented minority students and female students were recruited to participate in the research activities of this proposal.

 

PRODUCTS AND TRAINING

Tutorials and keynotes presented: 19

Publications in journals and conferences: 35

Patents granted in US: 1

Grauate students involved: 12

Undergraduates involved: 10

Post-docs mentored: 2 at  Clemson

New courses introduced: One at Clemson taken by 14 grad students and 10 u/g students.
